msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah

ab.title: Deuteronomy 2
ab.l:
And we turned and set out to the wilderness
by the way of the Red Sea, as the Lord spoke to me. And we went around
Mount Seir many days.

And the Lord spoke
to me, saying,

“You have had enough of going around
this mountain. Turn northward.

And direct the people, saying, “You are passing
through the border of your brothers, the children of Esau, who dwell in Seir.
And they will be afraid of you, take good heed to yourself.

Do not get excited about them: I will not give you any of their land,
|not so much as| for the sole of the foot to tread on, because
I have given Mount Seir to Esau for inheritance.

You shall buy food
from them for silver and you shall eat. And you shall also buy water from them
for silver, and you shall drink.

For the Lord your God has blessed
you in all the works of your hand. He knows your walking through this great wilderness.
These forty years the Lord your God is with you: you have not lacked
a thing.””

And we passed by our brothers, the children
of Esau, who dwelt in Seir, through the way of the steppe
from Elath and from Ezion-Geber, and we turned and passed
by the way of the wilderness of Moab.

And the Lord said
to me, “Do not oppress the Moabites, and no not ready yourselves for a battle with them, for I will not give you any of their land for inheritance, because
I have given Ar to the children of Lot for inheritance.”

The Emim
dwelt there originally, a people great and many and tall
like the Anakim:

Who also were considered Rephaim,
like the Anakim, but the Moabites called
them Emim.

And, originally, the Horites dwelt
in Seir, but the children of Esau drove them out from before
their children, and they destroyed them from before
them, and dwelt in their place, as
Israel did to the land of his inheritance, which the Lord gave to them.

“Now rise, and cross the river Zered.”
And we crossed the river Zered.

And the days
that we went from Kadesh-Barnea, until we crossed the river
Zered, was thirty-eight years, until the end of all the generation, of the men of war,
from among the camp, as the Lord swore to them.

For also the wrath of the Lord was against them and stirred
them out from the midst of the camp until their end.

And it was, when all the men of war had ended,
to die from among the people,

That the Lord spoke
to me, saying,

“Today, you are passing over through Ar, the border
of Moab.

And come near opposite
the children of Ammon, do not oppress them, do not get excited
about them, because I will not give you any of the land of the children of Ammon
for inheritance, because I have given it to the children of Lot
for inheritance.”

That also was regarded as a land Rephaim:
Rephaim dwelt there originally, and the Ammonites
call them Zamzummim.

A people great
and many and tall like the Anakim, but the Lord destroyed them
before them, and they drove them out and dwelt
in their place,

As he did to the children of Esau,
who dwelt in Seir, when he destroyed the
Horites from before them, and they drove them out and dwelt
in their place to this day.

And
the Avvim who dwelt in Hatzerim as far as Gaza,
the Caphtorim who came out of Caphtor destroyed them and dwelt
in their place.

“Rise up, set out
and pass over the river Arnon. See: I have given to your hand
Sihon the Amorite, king of Heshbon, and his land. Begin to destroy it.
Ready yourselves for a battle with him.

Today
I will begin to put the dread of you and the fear of you on the faces
of the peoples that are under the whole heaven, so that
they shall hear the news of you, and they shall tremble and dread before you.”

And I sent messengers out of the wilderness of Kedemoth
to Sihon, king of Heshbon, with words of peace, saying,

“Let me pass through your land by the road.
I will go along the way, I will not turn either to the right or to the left.

You shall sell me food for silver, that I may eat, and
you shall give me water for silver, that I may drink. Only let me pass through on foot,

As the children of Esau who dwell
in Seir, and the Moabites who dwell in Ar did for me,
until I shall pass over Jordan to the land which
the Lord our God gives us.”

But Sihon,
king of Heshbon, did not want to let us pass by his own land, because
the Lord your God hardened his spirit and strengthened
his heart in order to give him to your hand —
as it is this day.

And the Lord said to me, “See: I have begun
to give Sihon and his land before you. Begin
to destroy it, to inherit his land.”

And
Sihon came out against us, he and all his people, for war
at Jahaz.

And the Lord our God gave him
before us, and we defeated him and his sons and
all his people.

And we took all his cities
at that time and we put to destruction all the men
of the cities and the women and the infants. We did not leave a remnant.

Only the livestock we plundered for ourselves, and the spoil
of the cities which we took.

From Aroer,
which is by the bank of the river of Arnon, and the city that
is at the river, and to Gilead, there was no city that was stronger
than us. The Lord our God put it all
before us.

Only to the land of the children of Ammon
you did not come near, all the place of the river Jabbok and the cities of mountains,
and all that the Lord our God commanded.

app.note: Heb. רְפָאִים , i.e. the name of a Biblical race of giants, the pre-Israelite dwellers of the Land of Canaan. Cf. also Deu 2:20, Deu 3:11.
A mistranslation based in interpreting Heb. חָצֵרִים ‘villages’, ‘settlement without walls’ as a place name.
